programme.desc: Michael Portillo ventures into the Black Forest to discover the essence of Germany, and at Goettingen he discovers two sides of student life at the turn of the 20th century.(n)

programme.title: Games Britannia
programme.desc: Historian and broadcaster Benjamin Woolley explores the history of games in Britain. He discovers playing games was associated with gambling in the late Middle Ages, but a moral backlash in Victorian times transformed them into tools for moral education - and led to the development of the world's first games industry, with ludo, snakes & ladders and the Staunton chess set among the biggest sellers.(n)

programme.title: Timeshift
programme.sub-title: Bullseyes and Beer - When Darts Hit Britain: Timeshift
programme.desc: Documentary about the history of darts, as it transformed from a traditional working-class pub game into a world-recognised sport, and the role television played in elevating competitors such as Alan Evans and Jocky Wilson into household names. With contributions from Eric Bristow, Bobby George, John Lowe and Phil Taylor. Narrated by Siobhan Finneran.(n)

programme.title: Gauguin - A Dangerous Life
programme.desc: A biography of Paul Gauguin, a committed multi-media artist who worked with the Impressionists and had a tempestuous relationship with Vincent van Gogh. He left his wife to bring up five children and used his colonial privilege to travel to Polynesia, where in his 40s he took 'wives' aged 13-15, creating images of them and their world that promoted a fantasy paradise of an unspoilt Eden in the Pacific.(n)

programme.title: A History of Art in Three Colours
programme.desc: Art historian James Fox turns his attention to blue, examining how the colour was originally created from lapis lazuli, an imported precious stone found in the East, and that the bright paint it produced captivated artists in the Middle Ages. He explores the renowned Florentine painter Giotto's ground-breaking religious frescoes in the Arena Chapel in Padua, and charts how the colour has also helped painters from more recent times, including Gaugin, Van Gogh and Picasso, to depict emotional depth.(n)

programme.title: The Joy of Painting
programme.desc: Bob Ross paints a wintry scene in which the glistening sun peeks through the trees to warm the cold day.(n)

programme.title: Being Beethoven
programme.desc: As the composer embarked on the extraordinary flowering of his late music, his health deteriorated and his desire for love and family tipped over into obsession. Musical highlights include Paul Lewis exploring the beauty and brutality of the Diabelli Variations, and the Takacs Quartet playing the Hymn of Thanksgiving from Op 132.(n)

programme.title: Coastal Path
programme.desc: Traversing the rugged and mysterious north Cornish coast, explorer Paul Rose's first stop is Morwenstow, where he squeezes into the Trust's smallest property, the Hawker's Hut. Built in the 1800s by opium-smoking poet Reverend Hawker, it is popular with walkers who add their own graffiti. Next, Paul enjoys a tour of the wild and majestic Tintagel Castle, before heading to Padstow where the Mayday 'Obby 'Oss celebrations are in full swing. Paul is then put through his paces by a group of youngsters training to be surf lifesavers at Newquay's Fistral beach.(n)

programme.title: The Joy of Painting
programme.desc: As night settles over a rocky coast, Bob Ross produces a warm glow in the sky in a painting on black canvas.(n)

programme.title: Bob Ross: The Happy Painter
programme.desc: Documentary taking a behind-the-scenes look at American painter Bob Ross's journey from humble beginnings to pop culture icon, charting how one local TV commercial evolved into a viral phenomenon that continues to inspire millions around the world. The film reveals the public and private sides of Bob Ross through accounts from close friends and family, childhood photographs and rare archive footage. Interviewees recount his gentle, mild-mannered demeanour and unwavering dedication to wildlife as well as disclosing little-known facts about his famous curly hair - which was naturally straight - and his fascination with fast cars.(n)

programme.title: Empire of the Tsars: Romanov Russia with Lucy Worsley
programme.desc: Lucy Worsley tells the story of the dynasty that ruled Russia for more than three centuries, including figures such as Peter the Great and Catherine the Great, the struggle against Napoleon in 1812, and the political murders of Nicholas II and his family in 1918. In the first edition, she investigates the beginning of the Romanovs' 300-year reign in Russia, and charts ruthless Tsar Peter the Great's rule, who acceded to the throne at the age of nine.(n)

programme.title: Russia on Four Wheels
programme.desc: Part one of two. Justin Rowlatt and Anita Rani set off on separate road trips across Russia from Sochi, the Black Sea resort hosting the 2014 Winter Olympics. Anita travels north and west in a Kombat, a Russian-built luxury armour-plated vehicle, and enters a thriving world of westernised entrepreneurs who are at the forefront of shaping a new and vibrant country. Meanwhile, Justin heads east in a Soviet-built UAZ jeep, encountering a world that seems hardly to have changed since the Cold War.(n)

programme.title: Storyville
programme.sub-title: Olympic Dreams of Russian Gold: Over the Limit - Storyville
programme.desc: An intimate portrait of the world's most outstanding rhythmic gymnast Margarita Mamun, the leading representative of the Russian national team. The film presents a groundbreaking year in her life, from the 2015 World Championships to the 2016 Olympic Games, offering unprecedented access to the hidden world of elite gymnasts and the challenging training regime demanded by the Russian system.(n)

programme.title: Dan Cruickshank: At Home with the British
programme.desc: Dan Cruickshank explores Britain's love affair with the terrace, charting the highs of Victorian industry, the lows of their post-war decline and on to their 21st-century regeneration - which for one street in Toxteth, Liverpool, even saw them awarded the 2015 Turner Prize.(n)

programme.title: Arena
programme.desc: Multimedia artist Rachel Maclean's film exploring societal pressures on women from the media. Two inmates in a surreal prison are forced to compete against each other in performing a series of strange tasks, but they find a way to subvert the rules of the system and expose the sinister truth that underpins their world.(n)

programme.title: The Joy of Painting
programme.desc: As night settles over a rocky coast, Bob Ross produces a warm glow in the sky in a painting on black canvas.(n)

programme.title: Empire of the Tsars: Romanov Russia with Lucy Worsley
programme.desc: Lucy Worsley tells the story of the dynasty that ruled Russia for more than three centuries, including figures such as Peter the Great and Catherine the Great, the struggle against Napoleon in 1812, and the political murders of Nicholas II and his family in 1918. In the first edition, she investigates the beginning of the Romanovs' 300-year reign in Russia, and charts ruthless Tsar Peter the Great's rule, who acceded to the throne at the age of nine.(n)

programme.title: Coastal Path
programme.desc: Paul Rose explores the spectacular coastline of southern Cornwall, discovering one of the world's finest stages at the Minack open-air theatre in Porthcurno. He also tries out the high-octane sport of coasteering on the Lizard Peninsula, joins a National Trust ranger for some clifftop wildlife spotting, and fires the Tudor cannons of Pendennis Castle in Falmouth.(n)

programme.title: The Joy of Painting
programme.desc: American artist Bob Ross demonstrates how to paints a wintry mountain scene using only grey and white tones.(n)

programme.title: The Human Body: Secrets of Your Life Revealed
programme.desc: Chris and Xand van Tulleken explore the secrets of the body, beginning with the changes it goes through. They examine why human childhood is longer than any other creature on earth, reveal the communities of microbes - the microbiome - that people cultivate throughout their lives, and uncover the mysterious trigger from child to adult.(n)

programme.title: Wild Swimming with Alice Roberts
programme.desc: Alice Roberts embarks on a personal quest to discover what lies behind the new-found passion for swimming in the wild that is sweeping Britain, visiting rivers and underground lakes and taking a skinny dip in a moorland pool.(n)

programme.title: Swimming Through the Seasons - The Hampstead Ponds
programme.desc: Documentary filmed over 12 months following people who use three swimming ponds on Hampstead Heath, where they meet to take on the weather, the water and life in general.(n)

programme.title: Being Beethoven
programme.desc: As the composer embarked on the extraordinary flowering of his late music, his health deteriorated and his desire for love and family tipped over into obsession.(n)

programme.title: Bob Ross: The Happy Painter
programme.desc: Documentary that takes a behind-the-scenes look at American painter Bob Ross's journey from humble beginnings to pop culture icon.(n)

programme.title: Andrew Marr's Great Scots: The Writers Who Shaped a Nation
programme.desc: The life of Walter Scott, the prolific novelist and poet who wrote swashbuckling tales of romance and derring-do. However, Andrew Marr reveals his lesser-known side as a political fixer who believed in a proud Scotland inside the UK. Scott brought George IV to his home country and, swathing him in tartan, created an enduring myth of Scotland as a place of romance populated by a brave race doing brave deeds, all clad in kilts.(n)

programme.title: The Joy of Painting
programme.desc: American artist Bob Ross demonstrates how to paints a wintry mountain scene using only grey and white tones.(n)

programme.title: Wild Swimming with Alice Roberts
programme.desc: Alice Roberts embarks on a personal quest to discover what lies behind the new-found passion for swimming in the wild that is sweeping Britain, visiting rivers and underground lakes and taking a skinny dip in a moorland pool.(n)

programme.title: Coastal Path
programme.desc: Paul Rose continues his journey by exploring the soft and rolling coastline of south Devon, taking a snorkelling trip around Burgh Island and hitching a ride on the Dartmouth to Paignton steam train.(n)

programme.title: The Joy of Painting
programme.desc: American artist Bob Ross offers tips and tricks as he paints a lakeside view, surrounded by golden autumn trees.(n)

programme.title: Emma
programme.desc: While continuing her efforts to set up Harriet and the vicar, Emma looks forward to meeting Frank Churchill at the Christmas party, but when he fails to show up she becomes the subject of Mr Elton's unwanted attention. Later, village gossip focuses on the arrival of Jane Fairfax and a piano she was given by a mystery admirer, leaving the matchmaker reluctant to believe Mr Knightley could have sent the gift. Drama, starring Romola Garai, Louise Dylan, Blake Ritson and Laura Pyper.(n)

programme.title: Rome Unpacked
programme.desc: Chef Giorgio Locatelli and art critic Andrew Graham-Dixon explore Italy's capital in search of the generations of ordinary Romans who have left their mark on the city's culture and gastronomy. In the first of two programmes, Giorgio leads Andrew to some of his personal favourite districts including Garbatella, Italy's first 'garden suburb', which boasts vibrant market stalls and village architecture, where he introduces him to the simplest Roman food. In turn, Andrew introduces Giorgio to some of the most moving pictures by Caravaggio, in what was once the city's foremost church for poor pilgrims.(n)

programme.title: Rome Unpacked
programme.desc: Chef Giorgio Locatelli and art critic Andrew Graham-Dixon conclude their exploration of Italy's capital. In the second of two programmes, as well as marvelling at the mosaics in the 12th-century Basilica di San Clemente, Andrew takes Giorgio to an ancient Roman schoolteacher's classroom. Then it's on to a true architectural and civic wonder - the vast Testaccio Slaughterhouse, where workers were once paid in offal. Travelling to the Palazzo Colonna, Andrew shows Giorgio the Beaneater by Carracci, a Baroque painting that makes an everyday subject extraordinary.(n)

programme.title: The Treasures of Ancient Rome
programme.desc: Alastair Sooke explores the artistic achievements of the Romans, tracing their progression from thieves and copycats to pioneers of the use of unflinching realism. Portraits from the Republic reveal how they captured lifelike images and immortalised figures such as Julius Caesar and Cicero using marble, bronze and paint. Alastair also looks at how Rome's first emperor, Augustus, used art as a tool to forge his dominion.(n)

programme.title: Art, Passion & Power: The Story of the Royal Collection
programme.desc: Andrew Graham-Dixon tells the story of the Royal Collection's remarkable resurrection. Following its fortunes from Charles II through to the 18th century and the enlightened collecting of George III, cameras reveal some of its greatest treasures, including a jewel-encrusted salt cellar in the shape of a castle and a gold State Coach.(n)

programme.title: Bought with Love: The Secret History of British Art Collections
programme.desc: Art historian Helen Rosslyn continues to explore impressive country houses, focusing on the Grand Tour era of the 18th century when aristocrats filled their homes with masterpieces by 17th-century classical painters. She visits Holkham Hall in Norfolk to view the collection there, explores the legacy of the Dukes of Richmond at Goodwood House, and learns how the one-time Lord Egremont of Petworth House in Sussex patronised JMW Turner.(n)

programme.title: The Joy of Painting
programme.desc: American artist Bob Ross offers tips and tricks as he paints a lakeside view, surrounded by golden autumn trees.(n)

programme.title: Rome Unpacked
programme.desc: Chef Giorgio Locatelli and art critic Andrew Graham-Dixon explore Italy's capital in search of the generations of ordinary Romans who have left their mark on the city's culture and gastronomy. In the first of two programmes, Giorgio leads Andrew to some of his personal favourite districts including Garbatella, Italy's first 'garden suburb', which boasts vibrant market stalls and village architecture, where he introduces him to the simplest Roman food. In turn, Andrew introduces Giorgio to some of the most moving pictures by Caravaggio, in what was once the city's foremost church for poor pilgrims.(n)

programme.title: Coastal Path
programme.desc: Explorer Paul Rose sets off from Ladram Bay, heading for the chalk cliffs of Beer Head in South Devon. Here John Scott takes him underground on a tour of Beer Quarry caves, where until a few years ago limestone had been extracted for almost 2,000 years. Continuing along the coastal path to Charmouth, he learns about fossil hunting and ammonites and after enjoying the wild orchids in the ancient wildflower meadows of West Hay farm, begins the steep climb up to Golden Cap, the highest point on the path with stunning views along the Jurassic Coast.(n)

programme.title: Sounds of the Sixties
programme.desc: Music from the Top of the Pops archives, featuring performances by acts including the Foundations, Procol Harum, the Bee Gees, the Rolling Stones, and Dave Dee, Dozy, Beaky, Mick and Tich.(n)

programme.title: Top of the Pops: 1989
programme.desc: Jackie Brambles, Bruno Brookes and Gary Davies present the edition first broadcast on Christmas Day. Performers include Bros, the Beautiful South, Jason Donovan, Marc Almond and Gene Pitney, Mike and the Mechanics, Michael Ball, Michael Jackson, Simple Minds, Madonna, Kylie Minogue, Cliff Richard and Prince.(n)

programme.title: Rodney P's Jazz Funk
programme.desc: Rapper Rodney P Edwards reveals how the first generation of British-born black youngsters was inspired by the avant garde musical fusions of black America in the '70s to lay the foundations of modern-day multiculturalism by creating the first black British music culture with the Jazz Funk movement. He meets key musicians including Leee John, lead singer of group Imagination, and Kenny Wellington, founding member of funk band Light of the World, as well as DJ s Cleveland Anderson and Carl Cox, and writer Robert Elms.(n)

programme.title: Hot Chocolate at the BBC
programme.desc: Compilation of BBC performances and rare interview extracts celebrating British pop group Hot Chocolate and in particular its lead soloist Errol Brown. The band's top 10 hits from the 1970s and early 1980s are showcased, alongside rarely seen early performances and cult fan favourites.(n)

programme.title: Top of the Pops
programme.desc: Margaret Thatcher's last full year as British prime minister contrasted with global political change, while in the music world Pete Waterman's final year of chart domination heralded the dawn of Madchester. Some female artists brought attitude and power to the year, while an unlikely duet between a '60s legend and an '80s icon proved a charttopper and Jive Bunny kept the less discerning happy. As far as Top of the Pops was concerned, Radio 1's old guard was stood down as a team of fresh-faced recruits helmed the show. Contributors include Jason Donovan, Lisa Stansfield, Shaun Ryder, Chris Rea, Marc Almond, Sharleen Spiteri, Jazzie B and Jenny Powell.(n)

programme.title: I Can Go for That: The Smooth World of Yacht Rock
programme.desc: The first of two programmes in which Katie Puckrik revisits a halcyon period of Los Angeles studio craft when studio-based artists such as the Doobie Brothers, Steely Dan and Hall & Oates produced the smoothest R'n'B and married it to adult themes about longing, aspiration and melancholy. In its day this music was never identified as a genre, but in the 21st Century, in a nod to its finely crafted nature, it's come to be known as yacht rock. Katie looks at the singer-songwriters of Laurel Canyon as well as soft rock pioneers such as the band America. Contributors include Jay Graydon, John Oates, Mark Ronson and JD Ryznar.(n)

programme.title: The Defiant Ones
programme.desc: The stories of music entrepreneurs Jimmy Iovine and Dr Dre continues. This instalment explores Jimmy's reputation as a fearless, talented and indefatigable producer and how he reached the West Coast following a successful collaboration with Patti Smith. He describes moving to Los Angeles to produce with Tom Petty and his secret relationship with Stevie Nicks. Dr Dre talks about provocative songs, such as Straight Outta Compton, which were shaped by the bitter race relations in LA, how NWA evolved into a force to be reckoned with, and a devastating personal loss that overshadowed his success.(n)

programme.title: Rodney P's Jazz Funk
programme.desc: Rapper Rodney P Edwards reveals how the first generation of British-born black youngsters was inspired by the avant garde musical fusions of black America in the '70s to lay the foundations of modern-day multiculturalism by creating the first black British music culture with the Jazz Funk movement. He meets key musicians including Leee John, lead singer of group Imagination, and Kenny Wellington, founding member of funk band Light of the World, as well as DJ s Cleveland Anderson and Carl Cox, and writer Robert Elms.(n)

programme.title: Hot Chocolate at the BBC
programme.desc: Compilation of BBC performances and rare interview extracts celebrating British pop group Hot Chocolate and in particular its lead soloist Errol Brown. The band's top 10 hits from the 1970s and early 1980s are showcased, alongside rarely seen early performances and cult fan favourites.(n)

programme.title: This Farming Life
programme.desc: Spring is in the air and John hires extra help for the lambing season, with New Zealander Emma helping a ewe to give birth to triplets and hoping the smallest and weakest one will survive. Martin invests in some hi-tech kit to alert him when his cows are calving and collects semen from his prize bull to sell, while Mel spends her birthday at a cattle auction.(n)

programme.title: The Riviera: A History in Pictures
programme.desc: Part one of two. Actor Richard E Grant follows in the footsteps of artists who lived and painted on France's Cote d'Azur, renowned for its sunny climate. The first edition focuses on the relationship between modern art and the location's development as an international tourist haven. Cezanne, Monet and Renoir were captivated by the light and colour of the landscape in the 19th century and their resultant work advertised the region's beauty. Meanwhile, the area's vivid hues inspired Henri Matisse to adopt a new palette that set modern art on the route to abstraction.(n)

programme.title: The Last Wave
programme.desc: As the residents of Brizan gather on the beach for the annual surf party, a strange cloud suddenly falls over the ocean. When it retreats, 10 competing surfers have disappeared and only their empty and abandoned boards are pushed back by the waves onto the shore. Supernatural French drama, starring David Kammenos and Marie Dompnier.(n)

programme.title: The Last Wave
programme.desc: The surviving surfers discover they are endowed with strange powers, while the cloud is about to appear again. Supernatural French drama, starring David Kammenos.(n)

programme.title: Imagine
programme.desc: Having reigned over musical theatre for nearly five decades, Andrew Lloyd Webber's music has delighted millions worldwide in hit shows like Jesus Christ Superstar, Evita, Cats and Aspects of Love. In this programme, the composer chats to Alan Yentob about his autobiography Unmasked, a candid and confessional account of his early life and career up to the opening of The Phantom of the Opera in 1986.(n)

programme.title: BBC Proms 2020
programme.desc: A BBC Grand Virtual Orchestra made up of more than 300 BBC musicians perform Beethoveniana by composer Iain Farrington, a brand new reworking of Beethoven's nine symphonies commissioned by the BBC Proms to celebrate the opening of the 2020 Proms season.(n)

programme.title: BBC Proms Classics
programme.desc: Katie Derham presents this 2017 concert by the City of Birmingham Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Mirga Grazinyte-Tyla. The show features Beethoven's Fifth Symphony, Stravinsky's Violin Concerto with soloist Leila Josefowicz, and a piece by Gerald Barry, featuring tenor Allan Clayton.(n)

programme.title: The Merchant of Venice: Royal Shakespeare Company
programme.desc: When a contract between Bassanio and Shylock is broken in Venice, simmering racial tensions boil over. A wronged father, and despised outsider, Shylock looks to exact the ultimate price for a deal sealed in blood. Polly Findlay directs this RSC production of Shakespeare's uncompromising play, with Makram J Khoury, Patsy Ferran and Jamie Ballard.(n)

programme.title: Institute
programme.desc: In a shadowy establishment, residents attempt to create order from the chaos of life. Carers become patients, memories fracture and relationships collide. Drama by the physical theatre company Gecko, starring Chris Evans and Vanessa Guevara Flores.(n)

programme.title: Shakespeare in Italy
programme.sub-title: Shakespeare in Italy with Francesco da Mosto
programme.desc: The historian concludes his tour of the country beginning with a visit to Venice, where he meets actor Ciaran Hinds to discuss why the Bard chose the city as the setting for The Merchant of Venice. Francesco is then joined by Mark Rylance in Rome as they explore how the playwright used the Italian capital for the plots of Julius Caesar and Antony and Cleopatra to avoid Elizabethan censors. Finally, on the island of Stromboli, off the northern coast of Sicily, Francesco uncovers the location for Shakespeare's late masterpiece - The Tempest.(n)

programme.title: TOTP2
programme.desc: Mark Radcliffe marks the final round of the FA Cup by providing football fans with a chance to revisit some of the best (and worst) songs produced to celebrate the tournament's conclusion over the years. Viewers at home will be able to make use of social media to vote for their favourite tunes, meaning that woeful ditties such as Manchester United's 1996 song Move Move Move, featuring a youthful Paul Scholes, David Beckham and the Neville brothers, could feature alongside the arguably more 'professional' sounding efforts of the London Community Gospel Choir, which sang Abide With Me - the FA Cup's traditional anthem - ahead of Chelsea's clash with Everton at Wembley in 2009.(n)

programme.title: Classic EastEnders
programme.desc: Roxy struggles with her betrayal of Ronnie, Christian reaches breaking point with Steven, while Sean careers dangerously out of control.(n)

programme.title: Classic EastEnders
programme.desc: Stacey's search for Sean takes her to Tanya's doorstep, Ian sets out to bring Lucy home, and Steven makes a serious accusation.(n)

programme.title: Classic EastEnders
programme.desc: Roxy turns to Christian for support, while Bianca strikes up a feud with the Masoods. Gus bids farewell to the Square, but not before gaining revenge on Sean.(n)

programme.title: Classic EastEnders
programme.desc: Ian's investigations lead to the truth about Steven, and Bianca tries Ricky's patience by refusing to back down to Zainab's demands.(n)

programme.desc: An intimate portrait of the world's most outstanding rhythmic gymnast Margarita Mamun, the leading representative of the Russian national team. The film presents a groundbreaking year in her life, from the 2015 World Championships to the 2016 Olympic Games, offering unprecedented access to the hidden world of elite gymnasts and the challenging training regime demanded by the Russian system.(n)

programme.title: Dan Cruickshank: At Home with the British
programme.desc: Dan Cruickshank explores Britain's love affair with the terrace, charting the highs of Victorian industry, the lows of their post-war decline and on to their 21st-century regeneration - which for one street in Toxteth, Liverpool, even saw them awarded the 2015 Turner Prize.(n)

programme.title: Arena
programme.desc: Multimedia artist Rachel Maclean's film exploring societal pressures on women from the media. Two inmates in a surreal prison are forced to compete against each other in performing a series of strange tasks, but they find a way to subvert the rules of the system and expose the sinister truth that underpins their world.(n)

programme.title: The Joy of Painting
programme.desc: As night settles over a rocky coast, Bob Ross produces a warm glow in the sky in a painting on black canvas.(n)

programme.title: Empire of the Tsars: Romanov Russia with Lucy Worsley
programme.desc: Lucy Worsley tells the story of the dynasty that ruled Russia for more than three centuries, including figures such as Peter the Great and Catherine the Great, the struggle against Napoleon in 1812, and the political murders of Nicholas II and his family in 1918. In the first edition, she investigates the beginning of the Romanovs' 300-year reign in Russia, and charts ruthless Tsar Peter the Great's rule, who acceded to the throne at the age of nine.(n)

programme.title: Coastal Path
programme.desc: Paul Rose explores the spectacular coastline of southern Cornwall, discovering one of the world's finest stages at the Minack open-air theatre in Porthcurno. He also tries out the high-octane sport of coasteering on the Lizard Peninsula, joins a National Trust ranger for some clifftop wildlife spotting, and fires the Tudor cannons of Pendennis Castle in Falmouth.(n)

programme.title: The Joy of Painting
programme.desc: American artist Bob Ross demonstrates how to paints a wintry mountain scene using only grey and white tones.(n)

programme.title: The Human Body: Secrets of Your Life Revealed
programme.desc: Chris and Xand van Tulleken explore the secrets of the body, beginning with the changes it goes through. They examine why human childhood is longer than any other creature on earth, reveal the communities of microbes - the microbiome - that people cultivate throughout their lives, and uncover the mysterious trigger from child to adult.(n)

programme.title: Wild Swimming with Alice Roberts
programme.desc: Alice Roberts embarks on a personal quest to discover what lies behind the new-found passion for swimming in the wild that is sweeping Britain, visiting rivers and underground lakes and taking a skinny dip in a moorland pool.(n)

programme.title: Swimming Through the Seasons - The Hampstead Ponds
programme.desc: Documentary filmed over 12 months following people who use three swimming ponds on Hampstead Heath, where they meet to take on the weather, the water and life in general.(n)

programme.title: Being Beethoven
programme.desc: As the composer embarked on the extraordinary flowering of his late music, his health deteriorated and his desire for love and family tipped over into obsession.(n)

programme.title: Bob Ross: The Happy Painter
programme.desc: Documentary that takes a behind-the-scenes look at American painter Bob Ross's journey from humble beginnings to pop culture icon.(n)

programme.title: Andrew Marr's Great Scots: The Writers Who Shaped a Nation
programme.desc: The life of Walter Scott, the prolific novelist and poet who wrote swashbuckling tales of romance and derring-do. However, Andrew Marr reveals his lesser-known side as a political fixer who believed in a proud Scotland inside the UK. Scott brought George IV to his home country and, swathing him in tartan, created an enduring myth of Scotland as a place of romance populated by a brave race doing brave deeds, all clad in kilts.(n)

programme.title: The Joy of Painting
programme.desc: American artist Bob Ross demonstrates how to paints a wintry mountain scene using only grey and white tones.(n)

programme.title: Wild Swimming with Alice Roberts
programme.desc: Alice Roberts embarks on a personal quest to discover what lies behind the new-found passion for swimming in the wild that is sweeping Britain, visiting rivers and underground lakes and taking a skinny dip in a moorland pool.(n)

programme.title: Coastal Path
programme.desc: Paul Rose continues his journey by exploring the soft and rolling coastline of south Devon, taking a snorkelling trip around Burgh Island and hitching a ride on the Dartmouth to Paignton steam train.(n)

programme.title: The Joy of Painting
programme.desc: American artist Bob Ross offers tips and tricks as he paints a lakeside view, surrounded by golden autumn trees.(n)

programme.title: Emma
programme.desc: While continuing her efforts to set up Harriet and the vicar, Emma looks forward to meeting Frank Churchill at the Christmas party, but when he fails to show up she becomes the subject of Mr Elton's unwanted attention. Later, village gossip focuses on the arrival of Jane Fairfax and a piano she was given by a mystery admirer, leaving the matchmaker reluctant to believe Mr Knightley could have sent the gift. Drama, starring Romola Garai, Louise Dylan, Blake Ritson and Laura Pyper.(n)

programme.title: Rome Unpacked
programme.desc: Chef Giorgio Locatelli and art critic Andrew Graham-Dixon explore Italy's capital in search of the generations of ordinary Romans who have left their mark on the city's culture and gastronomy. In the first of two programmes, Giorgio leads Andrew to some of his personal favourite districts including Garbatella, Italy's first 'garden suburb', which boasts vibrant market stalls and village architecture, where he introduces him to the simplest Roman food. In turn, Andrew introduces Giorgio to some of the most moving pictures by Caravaggio, in what was once the city's foremost church for poor pilgrims.(n)

programme.title: Rome Unpacked
programme.desc: Chef Giorgio Locatelli and art critic Andrew Graham-Dixon conclude their exploration of Italy's capital. In the second of two programmes, as well as marvelling at the mosaics in the 12th-century Basilica di San Clemente, Andrew takes Giorgio to an ancient Roman schoolteacher's classroom. Then it's on to a true architectural and civic wonder - the vast Testaccio Slaughterhouse, where workers were once paid in offal. Travelling to the Palazzo Colonna, Andrew shows Giorgio the Beaneater by Carracci, a Baroque painting that makes an everyday subject extraordinary.(n)

programme.title: The Treasures of Ancient Rome
programme.desc: Alastair Sooke explores the artistic achievements of the Romans, tracing their progression from thieves and copycats to pioneers of the use of unflinching realism. Portraits from the Republic reveal how they captured lifelike images and immortalised figures such as Julius Caesar and Cicero using marble, bronze and paint. Alastair also looks at how Rome's first emperor, Augustus, used art as a tool to forge his dominion.(n)

programme.title: Art, Passion & Power: The Story of the Royal Collection
programme.desc: Andrew Graham-Dixon tells the story of the Royal Collection's remarkable resurrection. Following its fortunes from Charles II through to the 18th century and the enlightened collecting of George III, cameras reveal some of its greatest treasures, including a jewel-encrusted salt cellar in the shape of a castle and a gold State Coach.(n)

programme.title: Bought with Love: The Secret History of British Art Collections
programme.desc: Art historian Helen Rosslyn continues to explore impressive country houses, focusing on the Grand Tour era of the 18th century when aristocrats filled their homes with masterpieces by 17th-century classical painters. She visits Holkham Hall in Norfolk to view the collection there, explores the legacy of the Dukes of Richmond at Goodwood House, and learns how the one-time Lord Egremont of Petworth House in Sussex patronised JMW Turner.(n)

programme.title: The Joy of Painting
programme.desc: American artist Bob Ross offers tips and tricks as he paints a lakeside view, surrounded by golden autumn trees.(n)

programme.title: Rome Unpacked
programme.desc: Chef Giorgio Locatelli and art critic Andrew Graham-Dixon explore Italy's capital in search of the generations of ordinary Romans who have left their mark on the city's culture and gastronomy. In the first of two programmes, Giorgio leads Andrew to some of his personal favourite districts including Garbatella, Italy's first 'garden suburb', which boasts vibrant market stalls and village architecture, where he introduces him to the simplest Roman food. In turn, Andrew introduces Giorgio to some of the most moving pictures by Caravaggio, in what was once the city's foremost church for poor pilgrims.(n)

programme.title: Coastal Path
programme.desc: Explorer Paul Rose sets off from Ladram Bay, heading for the chalk cliffs of Beer Head in South Devon. Here John Scott takes him underground on a tour of Beer Quarry caves, where until a few years ago limestone had been extracted for almost 2,000 years. Continuing along the coastal path to Charmouth, he learns about fossil hunting and ammonites and after enjoying the wild orchids in the ancient wildflower meadows of West Hay farm, begins the steep climb up to Golden Cap, the highest point on the path with stunning views along the Jurassic Coast.(n)

programme.title: Sounds of the Sixties
programme.desc: Music from the Top of the Pops archives, featuring performances by acts including the Foundations, Procol Harum, the Bee Gees, the Rolling Stones, and Dave Dee, Dozy, Beaky, Mick and Tich.(n)

programme.title: Top of the Pops: 1989
programme.desc: Jackie Brambles, Bruno Brookes and Gary Davies present the edition first broadcast on Christmas Day. Performers include Bros, the Beautiful South, Jason Donovan, Marc Almond and Gene Pitney, Mike and the Mechanics, Michael Ball, Michael Jackson, Simple Minds, Madonna, Kylie Minogue, Cliff Richard and Prince.(n)

programme.title: Rodney P's Jazz Funk
programme.desc: Rapper Rodney P Edwards reveals how the first generation of British-born black youngsters was inspired by the avant garde musical fusions of black America in the '70s to lay the foundations of modern-day multiculturalism by creating the first black British music culture with the Jazz Funk movement. He meets key musicians including Leee John, lead singer of group Imagination, and Kenny Wellington, founding member of funk band Light of the World, as well as DJ s Cleveland Anderson and Carl Cox, and writer Robert Elms.(n)

programme.title: Hot Chocolate at the BBC
programme.desc: Compilation of BBC performances and rare interview extracts celebrating British pop group Hot Chocolate and in particular its lead soloist Errol Brown. The band's top 10 hits from the 1970s and early 1980s are showcased, alongside rarely seen early performances and cult fan favourites.(n)

programme.title: Top of the Pops
programme.desc: Margaret Thatcher's last full year as British prime minister contrasted with global political change, while in the music world Pete Waterman's final year of chart domination heralded the dawn of Madchester. Some female artists brought attitude and power to the year, while an unlikely duet between a '60s legend and an '80s icon proved a charttopper and Jive Bunny kept the less discerning happy. As far as Top of the Pops was concerned, Radio 1's old guard was stood down as a team of fresh-faced recruits helmed the show. Contributors include Jason Donovan, Lisa Stansfield, Shaun Ryder, Chris Rea, Marc Almond, Sharleen Spiteri, Jazzie B and Jenny Powell.(n)

programme.title: I Can Go for That: The Smooth World of Yacht Rock
programme.desc: The first of two programmes in which Katie Puckrik revisits a halcyon period of Los Angeles studio craft when studio-based artists such as the Doobie Brothers, Steely Dan and Hall & Oates produced the smoothest R'n'B and married it to adult themes about longing, aspiration and melancholy. In its day this music was never identified as a genre, but in the 21st Century, in a nod to its finely crafted nature, it's come to be known as yacht rock. Katie looks at the singer-songwriters of Laurel Canyon as well as soft rock pioneers such as the band America. Contributors include Jay Graydon, John Oates, Mark Ronson and JD Ryznar.(n)

programme.title: The Defiant Ones
programme.desc: The stories of music entrepreneurs Jimmy Iovine and Dr Dre continues. This instalment explores Jimmy's reputation as a fearless, talented and indefatigable producer and how he reached the West Coast following a successful collaboration with Patti Smith. He describes moving to Los Angeles to produce with Tom Petty and his secret relationship with Stevie Nicks. Dr Dre talks about provocative songs, such as Straight Outta Compton, which were shaped by the bitter race relations in LA, how NWA evolved into a force to be reckoned with, and a devastating personal loss that overshadowed his success.(n)

programme.title: Rodney P's Jazz Funk
programme.desc: Rapper Rodney P Edwards reveals how the first generation of British-born black youngsters was inspired by the avant garde musical fusions of black America in the '70s to lay the foundations of modern-day multiculturalism by creating the first black British music culture with the Jazz Funk movement. He meets key musicians including Leee John, lead singer of group Imagination, and Kenny Wellington, founding member of funk band Light of the World, as well as DJ s Cleveland Anderson and Carl Cox, and writer Robert Elms.(n)

programme.title: Hot Chocolate at the BBC
programme.desc: Compilation of BBC performances and rare interview extracts celebrating British pop group Hot Chocolate and in particular its lead soloist Errol Brown. The band's top 10 hits from the 1970s and early 1980s are showcased, alongside rarely seen early performances and cult fan favourites.(n)

programme.title: This Farming Life
programme.desc: Spring is in the air and John hires extra help for the lambing season, with New Zealander Emma helping a ewe to give birth to triplets and hoping the smallest and weakest one will survive. Martin invests in some hi-tech kit to alert him when his cows are calving and collects semen from his prize bull to sell, while Mel spends her birthday at a cattle auction.(n)

programme.title: The Riviera: A History in Pictures
programme.desc: Part one of two. Actor Richard E Grant follows in the footsteps of artists who lived and painted on France's Cote d'Azur, renowned for its sunny climate. The first edition focuses on the relationship between modern art and the location's development as an international tourist haven. Cezanne, Monet and Renoir were captivated by the light and colour of the landscape in the 19th century and their resultant work advertised the region's beauty. Meanwhile, the area's vivid hues inspired Henri Matisse to adopt a new palette that set modern art on the route to abstraction.(n)

programme.title: The Last Wave
programme.desc: As the residents of Brizan gather on the beach for the annual surf party, a strange cloud suddenly falls over the ocean. When it retreats, 10 competing surfers have disappeared and only their empty and abandoned boards are pushed back by the waves onto the shore. Supernatural French drama, starring David Kammenos and Marie Dompnier.(n)

programme.title: The Last Wave
programme.desc: The surviving surfers discover they are endowed with strange powers, while the cloud is about to appear again. Supernatural French drama, starring David Kammenos.(n)

programme.title: Imagine
programme.desc: Having reigned over musical theatre for nearly five decades, Andrew Lloyd Webber's music has delighted millions worldwide in hit shows like Jesus Christ Superstar, Evita, Cats and Aspects of Love. In this programme, the composer chats to Alan Yentob about his autobiography Unmasked, a candid and confessional account of his early life and career up to the opening of The Phantom of the Opera in 1986.(n)

programme.desc: The Duchess of Cambridge speaks to BBC Breakfast's Louise Minchin about early years development, the gap in support given to parents before children start school, and the difficulties of life in lockdown for many families. programme.title: Panorama
programme.desc: The World Health Organisation urged countries to stamp out infections as soon as they developed, but the UK government's initial scientific advice said the route out of the crisis was for most of us to catch the virus so we could develop 'herd immunity'. Dr Faye Kirkland investigates this approach to the Covid-19 pandemic, asking whether it was a dangerous gamble with people's lives or a sound scientific method. Faced with a growing backlash and warnings that the NHS was close to being overwhelmed, politicians denied herd immunity was the policy and within a few days Britain pivoted to a new strategy - lockdown.(n)

programme.title: Panorama
programme.desc: The World Health Organisation urged countries to stamp out infections as soon as they developed, but the UK government's initial scientific advice said the route out of the crisis was for most of us to catch the virus so we could develop 'herd immunity'. Dr Faye Kirkland investigates this approach to the Covid-19 pandemic, asking whether it was a dangerous gamble with people's lives or a sound scientific method. Faced with a growing backlash and warnings that the NHS was close to being overwhelmed, politicians denied herd immunity was the policy and within a few days Britain pivoted to a new strategy - lockdown.(n)

programme.title: Duchess of Cambridge: BBC Tiny Happy People
programme.desc: The Duchess of Cambridge speaks to BBC Breakfast's Louise Minchin about early years development, the gap in support given to parents before children start school, and the difficulties of life in lockdown for many families. The Duchess was speaking as part of her involvement with 'Tiny Happy People', a BBC initiative to support parents and carers in developing the language and communication skills of 0-4 year olds.(n)

programme.sub-title: Percy am Mathan Ban (Percy the Polar Bear)
programme.desc: Following the activities of a 10-week-old polar bear being raised by his mother in the Canadian Arctic. Percy was born during the winter in a den kept up to 40 degrees warmer than outside, where the temperature drops to minus 60C and it is dark for months. Polar bears have thick coats, a 10cm thick layer of blubber that acts like thermal underwear, and huge fur-covered paws that are like snowshoes.(n)

programme.desc: Using dramatic reconstructions and expert opinion, John Morrison revisits the story of John Donald Merrett - a murderer who, having been cleared of killing his mother in 1927, spent the next 30 years on a spree across Europe, spending a large inheritance on women and the black market. programme.sub-title: Percy am Mathan Ban (Percy the Polar Bear)
programme.desc: Following the activities of a 10-week-old polar bear being raised by his mother in the Canadian Arctic. Percy was born during the winter in a den kept up to 40 degrees warmer than outside, where the temperature drops to minus 60C and it is dark for months. Polar bears have thick coats, a 10cm thick layer of blubber that acts like thermal underwear, and huge fur-covered paws that are like snowshoes.(n)
